stem: An 84-year-old client with Type 2 Diabetes is admitted with profound dehydration and confusion. Based on the documentation in the Metabolic Monitoring & Hydration Index tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Acute hyperglycemic crisis in an elderly client.
Background: T2D for 30 years. Recently treated for a respiratory infection.
Assessment: Client is stuporous; dry mucous membranes; skin tenting present.
Recommendation: Aggressive isotonic rehydration.

tabs.title: Metabolic Monitoring & Hydration Index
tabs.content:
Assessment ItemCurrent FindingInterpretation
Blood Glucose1,120 mg/dLExtreme Hyperglycemia
Serum Osmolality350 mOsm/kg (High)Severe Hemoconcentration
Arterial pH7.36 (Normal)No Acidosis
Urine KetonesNegative to TraceNo Ketosis
Serum Bicarbonate24 mEq/L (Normal)Normal base balance

actionOptions.text: Administer 0.9% Normal Saline boluses until BP stabilizes
Initiate IV Regular insulin after starting fluid resuscitation
Administer Sodium Bicarbonate IV for acidosis

parameterOptions.text: Mental status and neurological assessments (Seizure risk)
Hourly blood glucose and serum electrolytes
Serial arterial blood gas (ABG) for pH trends
Peak flow meter readings every 4 hours

rationale.correct: This client is experiencing Hyperosmolar Hyperglycemic State (HHS) (c2), which occurs primarily in Type 2 Diabetics. Differentiating factors from DKA include: Glucose MUCH higher (>600-1000), normal pH (no acidosis), and no ketones. Rehydration (a1) is the most critical step because the client is profoundly dehydrated. Insulin (a2) is given to lower the glucose but must follow fluids to prevent circulatory collapse. Monitoring Neuro status (p1) is vital since rapid changes in osmolality can cause cerebral edema, and glucose (p2) must be tracked hourly.
clinicalPearls: HHS has a higher mortality rate than DKA because it affects older patients with more comorbidities.
The 'Ketones' are negative in HHS because Type 2 diabetics still have enough endogenous insulin to suppress lipase and prevent ketone formation, but not enough to control glucose.
The number one cause of HHS is infection (UTI/Pneumonia).

questionTrap.howToOvercome: HHS is NOT acidotic. If the pH is normal (7.35-7.45), you do NOT give bicarbonate.
